name: Grenade Matrix
description: A team of players is stuck in a building, and grenades are being thrown into the building. Hence, a matrix of size MxN is formed, with players, grenades and empty spots where the grenades are denoted by “G”, the players are denoted by “P”, and empty spots denoted by “*”. The player will die if there is a grenade in any of the 8 blocks surrounding the player. Count the number of players that survive the grenade attacks.
explainInput:
The first line contains X number of test cases.
The second line contains M and N, number of columns and rows respectively.
The next N lines contains M non-spaced characters to form the matrix.
explainOutput: X lines contains number of players that survive.
explanation: There are a total of 8 players, out of which 4 have grenades in adjacent blocks. Hence 4 players survive the blast.

name: Zombie Mode
description:
There’s a new Special Game Mode in PUBG called the Zombie Mode.
In order to win the game, you’ll have to kill all the zombies or survive till the time is over.
There are two types of Zombies : Giant Zombies and Small Zombies.
Giant Zombies moves at a speed of 1 block per second & takes 8 bullets to be killed.
Small Zombies moves at a speed of 2 blocks per second & takes 4 bullets to be killed.
You have N bullets at the start and you have to survive for M seconds to win the game. You can fire 4 bullets per second.
There are G no. of Giant Zombies and S no. of Small Zombies which are moving towards you at their respective speeds. Distances of all the Zombies from you is given. If they touch you then GAME OVER.
explainInput:
The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases.
Each test case contains 4 lines which are as follows :
The first line consists of two integers N and M respectively.
The second line contains of two integers G and S respectively.
The third line consists of G space-separated integers denoting distance of each Giant Zombie from you.
The fourth line consists of S space-separated integers denoting distance of each Small Zombie from you.
explainOutput: For each test case print a single line containing “WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER” without the quotes if you win else print “GAME OVER” without the quotes.
example:
Input:
3
50 10
3 4
8 10 9
2 15 12 9
35 10
3 4
5 7 9
4 16 2 20
50 10
3 4
6 2 10
10 20 5 16

Output:
WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER
GAME OVER
GAME OVER
explanation:
In Test Case 1: There are enough bullets to kill all the zombies and all the zombies can be killed before any zombie touches you.
In Test Case 2: There are not enough bullets to kill all the zombies.
In Test Case 3: There are enough bullets. But as you’ll first kill the Giant Zombie at distance 2 the Small Zombie with distance 5 will come at distance of 1 block and there’ll not be enough time for you to kill him before he touches you. If you try to kill the Small Zombie at distance 5 first, the Giant Zombie at distance 2 will kill you.

name: Aditya Loves PUBG
description:
“The early bird gets the first worm, but the wisest bird gets the fastest one.”

Aditya is really fond of playing PUBG. He is constantly finding ways to improve his game so that he can beat his friends Rohan and Raghav. Rohan and Raghav have been playing  PUBG since a year. So, both of them know how to win through practice. Aditya, on the other hand is a newbie. But, Aditya is smart. So, he is finding smart ways to win. 

The game has started. Aditya has to collect guns from various scattered places. 
You are being given the directions to collect the guns. Aditya has limited space in his bag. He has to follow the directions till the end and return back to the beginning to collect the guns. He has to choose the appropriate gun in order to maximise his killing efficiency.

A set of directions consists of several instructions. The first instruction is of the form "Start on XYZ", indicating the street that the route begins on. The next instruction is of the form “Left on abc” indicating the next road after collecting the gun.

Can you help Aditya figure out the best guns he can collect?
explainInput:
The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases.
The second line consists of an integer M which denotes the maximum weight of gun he can carry , an integer Z which denotes the total number of roads he has been to and integer N which denotes the total number of guns.
The third line contains N inputs of weights of the gun wt[i] and the fourth line contains corresponding power of those guns p[i]. 
The following Z lines give instructions showing his route:-
First line consists of the first road. The second line consists of the second road (along with change in direction).
Similar lines follow.
explainOutput:
Print Z lines containing his way back to the beginning road with the last traversed road as the first road and vice versa.
And the last line = Sum of the power of guns he can carry in horsepower.
example:
Input:
1
50 4 3
10 20 30
60 100 120
Start on xyz
Left on abc
Right on efg
Left on hgf

Output:
Start on hgf
Right on efg
Left on abc
Right on xyz
220
explanation: The directions given are to be traced back in the opposite direction and printed. The maximum weight he can carry is 50. So, the best way possible is to carry the guns with weights 20 and 30. So, total power is 100+120 = 220.

name: Drake Loves Kiki
description: Problem Author: Sanket Bailmare Drake loves to compose songs. This time he decides to compose in the language and grammar of his own. He decides to construct the words dictionary which would help him to compose his song. This time when he decides to something different, he tries to impress Kiki with the lines having some pattern. He shows T cases having N words each to Kiki to impress her. She gets impressed when she sees that each word is starting with a letter same as the ending letter of preceding word. You have to tell whether Kiki is Impressed with Drake or not.
explainInput: The first line of input contain an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists number of words N followed by space separated N words(small case) on the next line.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line “impressed” if the condition is satisfied. And “disappointed” if condition is not satisfied.
example: Input: 3 4 abcd defg qhij oklm 3 mcqz zqed defg 3 abcd klmn dejk Output: disappointed impressed impressed
explanation: In test case 1 words “abcd” & “defg” satisfy the criteria but the remaining words do not satisfy hence kiki is disappointed with these words. In test case 2 words are arranged in the order where the condition is satisfied hence kiki is impressed. In test case 3 words can be arranged in order to meet the condition hence kiki is impressed.

name: The Chat Pattern
description: Problem Author: Vipul Raghuvanshi Its the final year of engineering, Vipul and Yash are best friends since FE. They have a peculiar texting pattern when they chat during some exciting talks. The pattern is all the words should start with uppercase character and also ends with uppercase character following the rule of alternate uppercase and lowercase characters. In case of even word length, the two characters at the centre can have same case (uppercase / lowercase). Yash is thinking of some algorithm to convert all his text messages in the required pattern. Help Yash to write a program for this problem.
explainInput: The first line of input contain an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of one line, which contains a string S which denotes a text of N words with L characters each.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line which contains the text following pattern.
example: Input: 2 Bohot Hard Bohot Zyaada Hard Output: BoHoT HarD BoHoT ZyAAdA HarD
explanation: Both the output strings are following the required pattern.

name: TML Events
description: Problem Author: Shridhar Ravi TML is around the corner and GSTians are excited about it. Omkar has been chosen as the Fest Coordinator this year. He has introduced a new system of participating in the events this TML. There are N different events with some entry fees. With this new system of his, students can buy an Entry card worth Rs. K. But, this card is non-rechargeable and can be used exactly for 2 events, such that the entry fees of both the events are not greater than Rs. K. Omkar has listed all the events and their entry fees and has Q queries. He has specified a range of events, from L to R (both L and R inclusive). He needs your help to know how many different combinations of events a student can participate in the specified range for a card worth Rs. K.
explainInput: The first line of the input contains two space-separated integers N and Q, denoting the number of events and the number of queries respectively. The next line contains N space-separated integers denoting the entry fees of each event. The next Q lines contain 3 space-separated integers L, R, and K denoting the range and worth of the entry card respectively.
explainOutput: For each query Q, output the integer denoting the different combinations of events possible.
explanation:
For the 1st query, there is only one combination possible in the given range:
2nd event (Fee: 1) + 3rd Event (Fee: 2)=3

For the 2nd query, there are 4 combinations possible in the given range:
2nd event (Fee: 1) + 3rd Event (Fee: 2)=3 (which is less than card’s worth K=4)
2nd event (Fee: 1) + 4th Event (Fee: 3)=4
2nd event (Fee: 1) + 5th Event (Fee: 2)=3 (which is less than card’s worth K=4)
3rd event (Fee: 2) + 5th Event (Fee: 2)=4

name: TE'S And Their Project Groups
description: Problem Author: Pritam Negi Third year Engineering students are just about to finish their term of Semester 6. As they are nearing their entry into the final year of Engineering now they have been informed to form their project groups by the end of Semester 6. Now the students want to include only those students in their project groups whom they have synergy with. Also the condition according to the university norms is that every project group must contain at least 2 members but not more than 4 members. So a project group is considered as valid if it satisfies the above condition. The existence of synergy is mutual i.e. if student i has synergy with student j then student j has synergy with student i as well. Also the existence of synergy is transitive. This means that if student i is has synergy with student j AND student j has synergy with student k, then student i and student k will have synergy among each other. This complicates the task for the Project Coordinator to determine the number of valid project groups that exist in the whole class. Hence she needs your help. Given the number of students and synergy list help project coordinator determine the number of valid project groups.
explainInput: The first line of the input contains a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. The description of T test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains two space-separated integers N and M, denoting the number of students and the number of synergy relations, respectively. Each of the following M lines contains two space-separated integers i and j, denoting student i and student j have synergy among themselves.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line containing two space separated integers, denoting the maximum number of valid project groups that can be formed.
constraints:
1<= T <= 5
1<= N <= 10<sup>5</sup>
1<= M <= 10<sup>5</sup>
1 <= i,j <= N
i ≠ j
For any pair of student i and j such that 1 ≤ i < j ≤ N, at most one pair among (i, j) and (j, i) will appear in the input.
explanation: TEST CASE 1: In this case student 1 has synergy with student 2. Student 2 in turn has synergy with student 3. Hence student 1,2,3 can form a project group of 3 members. Student 4 has synergy with no other student hence cannot be considered as a valid project group. Hence only 1 valid project group exists in this case. TEST CASE 2: In this case student 1 has synergy with student 2 so they can form a form a group of 2 members. Same goes for group of students 3, 4 and 5, 6. Hence 3 valid project groups exist in this case.

name: Swedish House Mafia ⚫️⚫️⚫️
description: Problem Author: Omkar Prabhu Lets celebrate 03 25 18! You are given a very long number, find if it is divisible by 03 or not.
explainInput:
The first line contains T the number of test cases.
Each test case contains a number N.
explainOutput: For each test case, print single line containing greyhound or untilone if number is divisible by 03 or not respectively.
explanation: Listen to them here: Axwell: In My Mind Sebastian Ingrosso: Reload Steve Angello: Payback

name: Consistent brand
description: Problem Author: Kaustubh Badrike As always, Raju the marketing coordinator is looking for sponsors to the upcoming fest. This time, he’s set his sights on notebook brands. To compare brands, he’s collected N notebooks from all over the campus. However, he doesn’t want just any brand, he’s looking for a brand with the longest consistent streak. A brand is said to have a consistent streak if the number of pages of the brand’s ith occurrence is the same as the number of pages of the brand’s (i+1)th occurrence. If two brands have the same length of the longest consistent streak, the brand with more number of pages in it’s longest consistent streak is preferred. If the number of pages in the longest consistent streak is also the same for two brands, the brand appearing earlier in the dictionary is preferred.
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of three lines. The first line of each test case consists of a single integer, N. The second line consists of N space-separated strings, where the nth string denotes the brand of the nth notebook. The third line consists of N space-separated integers, where the nth integer denotes the number of pages of the nth notebook.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the brand having the longest consistent streak.
example: Input: 1 9 A C B C B A B C A 2 6 7 4 5 4 5 6 8 Output: B
explanation: The 2<sup>nd</sup> and 3<sup>rd</sup> occurrences of B have the same number of pages (5). Hence the brand B has the longest consistent streak (length 2).

name: Don't You Worry Child (Surprise Problem)
description: Problem Author: Omkar Prabhu When we thought of this contest at first, we all were like, “wow, we would tell our college stories!" and soon we all realised that time really flied in these 4 years... What did we care about the most in these 4 years? Marks? Attendance? Assignments? Huh, NO! We made sure we are learning in all aspects and get inspired every single day to come up with new ideas and new projects or something new to keep us happy. Want to feel that vibe to come to college for your remaining years? Find that "one thing" which you feel interesting. No matter what it is, it can be music, academics, tech, drama, dance, logistics, marketing, just get into that damn thing and explore! But, we all experienced one common thing, "ye semester chod, agle semester pakka 7+ or 8+ or 9+ launga!". So here you are. You will be given marks of N subjects and you are given S semesters. Let's define an array A with size N x S as the array that's formed by concatenating S copies of N. For example, if N = {6, 9} and S = 3, then A = {6, 9, 6, 9, 6, 9}. You have to find the maximum subarray sum of the new array. Fomally, you should compute the maximum value of Ai + Ai+1 + Ai+2 + ... + Aj, where 0 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ (N x S).
explainInput:
The first line of the input contains a single integer T denoting the number of test cases.
The first line of each test case contains two space-separated integers N and S.
The second line contains N space-separated integers.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line containing the maximum subarray sum of the new array A.
explanation:
Case 1: A = {1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2} and the subarray with maximum sum is the whole {1, 2, 1, 2, 1, 2}. So the answer is 9.
Case 2: A = {1, -2, 1, 1, -2, 1} and the subarray with maximum sum is {1, 1}. So the answer is 2.

name: Miu hates rectangles
description: Miu - The smart cat is back Today she came across a set of cardboard boxes arranged on the floor The boxes are arranged in R rows and C columns ( R is not equal to C ) Miu doesn’t like this arrangement since they form a rectangle She wants to know if it is possible to rearrange them in a form of a square of side length greater than or equal to N ( It is allowed to discard some of the boxes ) Since Miu is short of sleep and low on coffee, she is not able to think properly Help her to find out if this is possible or not
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases (i.e queries) The only line of each test case consists 3 space-separated integers R, C and N
explainOutput: For each test case, output the answer in a single line: 1 -> if it is possible 0 -> if it is not possible
explanation: Test Case 1: the number of boxes available aren’t enough for making a 3 by 3 arrangement Test Case 2: the number of boxes available are enough for making a 2 by 2 arrangement

name: Swapnil and his autocorrect
description: Swapnil has got a new phone! But guess what, its keyboard’s autocorrect system is annoying. Whenever the autocorrect changes Swapnil’s word into a wrong word, he retypes a new word with an asterisk (*) at the beginning. You will be given N words sent by Swapnil. Print the exact message Swapnil wants to convey in the format given below.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of Test Cases. The first line of each test case consists of a single integer N. The next N lines consists of the N words sent by Swapnil
explainOutput:
For each test case, print the exact message Swapnil wanted to convey with each word on a new line.
(See example for clarification)
constraints:
• 1 <= T <= 10
  • 1 <= N <= 1000
  • All strings are only formed with lower case alphabets and asterisk (*)
  • The length of any string doesn’t exceed 20
  • No two consecutive words in the input begin with an asterisk (*)
    ( i.e. swapnil corrects any wrong word in one shot )
  • The first word of any test case doesn’t begin with an asterisk
example: Input: 3 8 hellow *hello my game *name is swap *swapnil 5 i am learning backpain *blockchain 4 hey how you doin Output: hello my name is swapnil i am learning blockchain hey how you doin
explanation:
The incorrect words were removed.
Note that the asterisk is removed from the corrected words.
The 3rd test case consists of no wrong words, so we print them as they are.

name: XOR Modification
description:
You are given two arrays A & B of length N, A1 A2… AN & B1 B2… BN You are supposed to do the following operation N times: For the (i)th number of operation:
  • Pick up the current largest element from the array A, let’s call it X
  • Delete X from the array A
  • Insert (X ^ Bi) anywhere in the array A
    ( where ^ denotes the bitwise XOR operation )
Finally print the final array A in ascending order
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. The first line of each test case consists of a single integer N The next line consists of N space-separated integers A1 A2… AN The next line consists of N space-separated integers B1 B2… BN
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line consisting of N space-separated integers, denoting the final array A sorted in ascending order.

name: Book Cricket
description: Piyush and Gokul were arguing during the lectures over who is the better cricket player out of the two. They decided to settle it through a book cricket match. Now, you have to determine who is the winner of the match. Both Piyush and Gokul have N no. of turns. They can score runs - 0,2,4,6,8 where 0 means OUT. The final score is the sum of runs. The player with maximum score wins. In case of a tie the player losing less wickets wins. If both players have the same final score and both have lost same no. of wickets then it’s a draw.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case contains 3 lines which are as follows: The first line consists of a single integer N denoting no. of turns. The second line consists of N space separated integers denoting runs scored by Piyush. The third line consists of N space separated integers denoting runs scored by Gokul.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line containing the name of the winner - 'Piyush’ or ‘Gokul’ without the quotes. In case of a draw print ‘Draw’ without the quotes. NOTE: The output is case sensitive. Please print the the exact words as mentioned above.
explanation: Test Case 1: The final score of Piyush is 24 runs with 1 wicket gone & final score of Gokul is 20 runs with 1 wicket gone. Since, final score of Piyush is more than Gokul, Piyush is the winner. Test Case 2: Both Piyush and Gokul have same final score of 20 runs but Piyush lost 1 wicket while Gokul lost 0. Since, Gokul lost less wickets than Piyush, Gokul won the match. Test Case 3: Both Piyush and Gokul have the same final score of 20 and both lost 1 wicket each. Since, their final scores and wickets lost are the same, it’s a Draw.

name: Keyboard Prank
description: Ashok’s laptop was hacked by Ninad as he decided to play a prank on him. He changed the settings of Ashok’s keyboard and replaced the output of letters ‘a’, ‘s’, ‘h’, ‘o’, ‘k’ with ‘n’, ‘i’, ‘n’, ‘a’, ‘d’ respectively. That is ‘a’ gets replaced with ‘n’ ‘s’ gets replaced with ‘i’ ‘h’ gets replaced with ‘n’ ‘o’ gets replaced with ‘a’ ‘k’ gets replaced with ‘d’ Now, whenever Ashok will send someone a message the letters will get replaced. You have to determine what message will be received. NOTE : The message string does not contain any spaces.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of a single line containing a string S that Ashok wants to send to his friend.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line which consists of the string which the receiver will receive.
constraints: 1< = T <= 1000 1 <= Length(S) <= 10^4 All the strings will have only lowercase alphabets.
example: Input: 3 ash ashok coffee Output: nin ninad caffee
explanation: Test Case 1: Here, ‘a’, ‘s’, ‘h’ gets replaced with ‘n’, ‘i’, ‘n’ respectively. Test Case 2: Here, ‘a’, ‘s’, ‘h’, ‘o’, ‘k’ gets replaced with ‘n’, ‘i’, ‘n’, ‘a’, ‘d’ respectively. Test Case 3: Here, ‘o’ in ‘coffee’ gets replaced with ‘a’ to give ‘caffee’.

name: Shiny Calculation
description: Red catches N pokemons. Whenever he catches a pokemon he documents it . If its a not shiny he writes 1 and if shiny he writes *. Write a code to find the percentage of shiny encounter for Red. Note: Only print the integer value of the percentage.
explainInput: The first line consists of a single integer T, the number of test cases The second line consists of a single integer N, the number of Pokemon caught by Red The third line consists of N characters: 1/* depending upon the catch of Red.
explainOutput: Output For each test case, print a single line consisting the shiny percentage followed by “%” Note: 3.99% will also be considered as 3% and not 4.
explanation: Test case 3: There are 2 shiny Pokemon out of 3. Therefore it becomes 66.66667% Since we are supposed to only print the integer value, the answer is 66%

name: Billy's PC
description: This is Billy here. I manage the trainers battle group and PC Pokemon all over the Kanto region. Since you have managed to solve two of the major issues I need someone to help me with some work . The back end code of the PC is not working anymore so i need your help to write a new one. When a trainers captures a new Pokemon we get input as “captured Pokemon_name” So if the trainer has less than 6 Pokemon on his team add that Pokemon to his team, otherwise it will be transferred to PC. When a trainer deposits a Pokemon to PC we get input as “deposit Pokemon_name” If he has only one Pokemon on his team and tries to deposit it, then the machine denies it automatically and you don’t need to code for that. When the trainer tries to withdraw a Pokemon. He can only carry 6 Pokemon, if he withdraws a Pokemon it will be added to the last position in his team. The machine doesn't allow the trainer to carry more than 6 Pokemon. Show the battle box to the trainer after all the operations.
explainInput: The first line consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. The first line of each test case consists of a single integer N, denoting the number of operations. Then N lines follow, consisting of strings which denotes the operations performed by the pc user.
explainOutput:
For each test case,
The output should consist of the names of the Pokemon on the trainers battle group, one on each line.
example:
INPUT-
1
13
captured treeco
captured larvitar
captured charmander
deposit treeco
captured beldum
captured totodile
captured metagross
captured gligar
deposit metagross
withdraw treeco
deposit charmander
captured mareep
captured chimchar
Output-

larvitar
beldum
totodile
gligar
treeco
mareep
explanation:
He captured Treeco,Larvitar and Charmander and then Treeco
so current team becomes
lavritar
charmander
then Captures beldum,totodile,metagross and gligar.
then deposit metagross and withdraws treeco and deposits charmander.
so current team is 
larvitar
beldum
totodile
gligar
treeco
and captured mareep and chimchar 
so final team is
larvitar
beldum
totodile
gligar
treeco
mareep

name: OH? Something is happening.
description: Barath and Mithil are playing Pokemon Go and are currently trying to hatch eggs. They want to find out a way to get rarer Pokemon. The more distance the egg takes to hatch the rarer the Pokemon is. There are 3 types of eggs in the game: 2Km, 5Km and 10Km eggs. You will be given an integer E, denoting the number of eggs they have and the distance required to hatch each egg, D[i]. You will also be given the number of trips N they took and distance travelled in each trip B[i] by Barath and M[i] by Mithil. 10Km egg has a rarity factor of 10. 5Km egg has a rarity factor of 5. 2km egg has a rarity factor of 2. They will incubate the egg with the most rarity factor first and only one egg can be incubated at at time. Also they will not incubate an egg with lesser rarity factor when an egg with higher factor exists You are supposed to find out who can have the higher rarity factor after N trips, Barath or Mithil.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases The first line of each test case consists of a single integer E The next line consists of E space-separated integers D[i] The next line consists of a single integer N, the number of trips Barath and Mithil went for The next line will consist of the distances travelled by Barath in his N number of trips B[i]. The next line will consist of the distances travelled by Mithil in his N number of trips M[i].
explainOutput:
For each test case,
The first line should have the name of trainer with higher rarity factor or “Draw” if both of them have the same rarity factors
The second line should have 2 space-separated integers, the rarity factors of Barath and Mithil respectively.
explanation: Test Case 1: Total distance travelled by barath -> 2 + 6 = 8 Since they won’t hatch any eggs with smaller rarity factor in existence of higher ones, Barath won’t go for the eggs with rarity factors of 5 Hence his final rarity factor remains 0 Total distance travelled by Mithil -> 4 + 7 = 11 Mithil can go for the egg with rarity factor 10 Later he remains with only 1 point ( 11 - 10 ), hence he stops Hence his final rarity factor is 10

name: Cirtangle
description: Mithil loves eating in a circular plate on a rectangular table surface. Lately he’s been visiting many places with different plate and table sizes. Mithil is happy only if the table is large enough to occupy the plate completely. The dimensions of the rectangular table surface are N x M. The radius of the circular plate is R. Can you tell if Mithil is happy or not?
explainInput:
• The first line of the input contains a single integer T denoting the number of test cases. The description of T test cases is as follow:
  • The first and only line of each test case contains 3 space separated integers N, M and R.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line containing the string "YES" if the table is large enough to occupy the plate or else "NO" (without quotes).
explanation: Example case 1: The table is large enough. Example case 2: No matter what, the dish is too large for the table.

name: Complex relationship
description: I was the 1, she said. But I was -ve about it. She rooted me out of her life. And now I … am just ‘i’. It’s all imaginary until I found a real friend, but now its complex. Help ‘i‘ resolve the complex after repeatedly multiplying this friendship N times by itself. You are given the complex number X + iY. Multiply i to this number N times. Output the resultant complex number.
explainInput:
• The first line of the input contains a single integer T denoting the number of test cases. The description of T test cases is as follow:
  • The first and only line of each test case contains 3 space separated integers N, X and Y.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line containing the real part and the imaginary part of the new complex separated by a space.
explanation: Example case 1: The complex number is 2-3i. Multiplying i once : 2i+3 Multiplying i again: -2+3i

name: Jagga plays TT
description: Jagadish is playing Table Tennis for the first time at our Indoor Play Area and he is interested to play this game but doesn’t know the game rules/basics. So, you’re assigned to be the assistant of Jagadish to let him know his score and status. If Opponent does incorrect service / strikes ball twice / fail to return, Jagadish will get +1 / 2 / 3 points, respectively. Jagadish is new to the game, so he is prone to failed services. After every three failed services, he will get a foul and will lose all his points. Every game lasts for N rounds from Jagadish and his opponent. Note: For Every Foul by Jagadish, his score is reset to 0 and his number of failed services is also reset to 0.
explainInput: First Line of Input contain an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each Test Case contains: First line would be N -> the length of string Second line would be a string of letters where: O denotes Incorrect Service by opponent B denotes Ball striking twice by opponent F denotes Failed return by opponent S denotes Failed Service by Jagadish
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the final score of Jagadish
explanation: In the first case, Jagadish scores +17 from (2 O’s, 3 B’s, 3 F’s) but the count of S becomes 3 at the end of string , so his score is 0. In the second case, Jagadish scores from (2 B’s, 1 O’s ,1 F’s) but after completion of 3 S’s, he scored FOBS(3+1+2) = 6 points Score is calculated as: (Number of O * 1) + (Number of B * 2) + (Number of F * 3) which will be equal to zero when Count of S turns to 3. When Count of S becomes 4, Count of S becomes 1 ( as it is reset to 0 after 3 failed services ) and Final Score of Jagadish is 6.

name: Catch-a Local
description: It’s College time and Surya is back into action. Surya needs to catch a local to reach college on time, so he wants to calculate if he could catch the train or not. There are N cases where Surya describes the M, S and T. Surya takes M time to reach the station, his station number (destination) is S and Train takes T time to reach this station. Also, Train stops for 20 extra seconds at each station for passengers to get down / up the train. Surya is lazy , so help him in checking whether he could catch the train or not.
explainInput: First Line of Input contain an integer N denoting the number of test cases. Each Test case consists of one line, which contains M (Time taken by Surya), S (Sth Station is the station to be reached), T (Time taken by train) in order. All time mentioned is in the format mm:ss(minutes:seconds) or mm(minutes) if the seconds part is zero/insignificant. Eg: 12:00 can be taken as 12 since seconds part of “12:00” is zero/insignificant, while 02:04 cannot be represented / accepted as 2:4 or 02:4 or 2:04.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the Result: “+seconds” or “-seconds”. i.e, ‘+’ for catching train and ‘-’ for missing the train, with the difference in time(seconds) taken by Surya to arrive as S and the train to depart from S .
explanation: In the first case, Surya takes 12 minutes to reach while Train takes {21:44+Delay} time , hence, Surya catches Train with 644 seconds remaining. In the second case, Surya missed train by 1080 seconds since train took (15:20+Delay} time to reach at and depart from S and Surya took 34 minutes to reach station.

name: Stage 1: Yusuf’s dream
description:
Cobb, Arthur, Eames, Ariadne and Yusuf are "extractors": they perform corporate espionage using experimental military technology to infiltrate the subconscious of their targets and extract valuable information through a shared dream world. Their latest client, Japanese businessman Saito, has a seemingly impossible job for the team: implanting an idea in a person's subconscious, or ‘inception’. To break up the energy conglomerate of ailing competitor Maurice Fischer, Saito wants Cobb to convince Fischer's son and heir, Robert, to dissolve his father's company via an ‘inception’.

The job is set into motion when Maurice Fischer dies and his son accompanies his father's body from Sydney to Los Angeles. During the flight, Cobb sedates Fischer, and the team brings him into a three-level shared dream.

In the first level, Yusuf's dream of a rainy city, the team successfully abducts Fischer, but the team is attacked by Fischer's militarized subconscious projections, which have been trained to hunt and kill extractors. 

The sedated team is travelling in a car, driven around by Yusuf. The car capable of handling a damage of at most X points. A series of attacks is inflicted on the car by the aforementioned projections. Each successful attack on the car (denoted by a positive value Y) inflicts a damage of amount Y, and each miss is denoted by a zero or a negative value Z. 

Can Cobb and his team survive the attack and make it to the second stage?
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of two lines; the first line contains the number of infliction N, and the damage-capacity X of the car; and the next line contains the series of attacks inflicted (series of integers Y and Z).
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the string “successful” or “unsuccessful” (without quotes).
explanation:
Case 1:
The total damage inflicted is less than the damage-capacity of the car.

Case 2:
The inflicted damage exceeds the damage-capacity of the car.

Case 3:
The total damage inflicted is equal to the damage-capacity of the car.

name: Stage 2: Arthur’s dream
description: Yusuf remains on the first level driving a van through the streets, while the remaining team successfully enter stage 2; Arthur's dream, taking place in a corporate hotel. The remainder of the team is sedated, while Arthur is bestowed with the responsibility of setting up the ‘kick’. A ‘kick’ is a sudden jolt that awakens the sleeper from the dream. The ‘kick’ in this stage is a set of bombs that need to detonate in synchronization. There are N bomb-sites, each having a detonation-value, i.e., amount of damage done when a bomb is placed at that particular site. Arthur’s objective is to place the bombs in a permutation, such that the overall detonation-value is maximized. However, placing two bombs adjacent to each other shall result in an unsynchronized detonation, which should be avoided at all costs. Shoot! The projections are firing at the team. Can you help Arthur in setting up the bombs and maximizing the detonation-value, while he takes care of the projections?
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of two lines; the first line contains the number of bomb-sites N, and the next line contains a series of detonation-values (ai) of the bomb-sites.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the maximum possible detonation value.
explanation:
Case 1:
Here, by adding a[1] + a[3] + a[5] we get the maximum detonation-value as 110.

Case 2:
Here, by adding a[0] + a[3] we get the maximum detonation-value as 45.

name: Stage 3: Eames’ dream
description:
Cobb, Eames, Ariadne, Saito and Fischer have reached the final stage of the espionage. All they gotta do is infiltrate the fortified hospital, and find Robert Fischer’s father. The team’s fighting off the projections, providing a cover for Fischer, who’s en route to find his father inside the hospital. He finally finds the safe room where his father is waiting for him. Fischer cannot enter the safe room as it is guarded by a security question which reads as follows: Given a string S of length N, comprising of only 0’s and 1’s, find:
  • the maximum number of 0’s that can be flipped to a 1, such that no two 1’s are adjacent in the string.
  • the string S’, after flipping the bits as mentioned above. If there is a possibility of flipping either of the 0’s (while the maximum number of flips remain the same), flip the 0 that occurs first in the input string (refer case 4 for better understanding).
Time is ticking away. Help Fischer meet his father to complete espionage successfully.
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. The first line of each test case contains a single integer N. The next line contains a single string S with length N. It is guaranteed that the given string S does not have adjacent 1’s.
explainOutput: For each test case, print two lines: the first line containing one integer - the maximum number of flips and second line containing the string S’.
explanation:
Case 1:
Here, only the 0 present in the 4<sup>th</sup> position can be flipped. Hence, maximum number of flips that can be made is equal to 1. The given string after the flip becomes: 010101.

Case 2:
Here, the 0’s present in the 1<sup>st</sup>, 9<sup>th</sup> and 11<sup>th</sup> position can be flipped. Hence, maximum number of flips that can be made = 3. The given string after the flips becomes: 10101010101.    

Case 3:
Here, the 0’s present in the 1<sup>st</sup> and 3<sup>rd</sup> position can be flipped. Hence, maximum number of flips that can be made = 2. The given string after the flips becomes: 101.    

Case 4:
Here, the 0 present in either the 3<sup>rd</sup> or 4<sup>th</sup> position can be flipped. Hence, maximum number of flips that can be made = 1. The given string after the flips becomes: 101001 as the first possible 0 is flipped.

name: So you think you can Dance?
description: Alice and Bob are keen dancers. They are currently practising to participate in an international dance contest! Alice has N energy pills which help her when she gets tired. She wants to share these pills with Bob in such a way that both Alice and Bob get equal amount of these pills. Find the maximum number of pills Bob can get.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of Queries (Test Cases) . Each query consists of a single line containing a single integer N.
explainOutput: For each query, output the answer in a single line .
explanation: There are 3 Queries. Query 1: 15 pills can be divided into 7, 7 & 1. Alice and Bob can have 7 pills each, which is the maximum amount satisfying the condition that both Alice and Bob get equal amount of pills.

name: So you think you can Math?
description: You are given a set consisting of N amount of even numbers and M amount of odd numbers. In one move, you have to take any two of these numbers, delete them from the set, and store back either their product or their summation. You have to continue this procedure until there is only one remaining element in the set. You are supposed to tell if it is possible to make some moves in such a way that the remaining element is odd.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of a single line containing two space-separated integers, N and M.
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line containing yes (strictly in lowercase) if it is possible to obtain an odd value, otherwise output no (strictly in lowercase) if it is not possible. Note: Make sure your output is in lowercase, otherwise the compiler won’t be able to match it with the correct answer.
explanation: There are 2 Test Cases: Test Case 1: There is 1 even number & 2 odd numbers. We can multiply the 2 odd numbers to obtain an odd number and then add it with the even number to again obtain an odd number. Hence it is possible.

name: So you think you can Dare?
description: You are playing Truth & Dare with Miu - The smart cat. It’s your turn and you chose to Dare! You have N sticks with you, each of the length from 1 to N. Miu destroyed one of these sticks, specifically of length X. Hence, now you have N-1 sticks left of all lengths from 1 to N except X. Now you are allowed to join all, some or none of these sticks together to form a longer stick. You are NOT allowed to break any stick. Miu dares you to form a stick of length exactly L using these N-1 sticks. Is it possible to complete this task?
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T denoting the number of test cases. The only line of each test case consists of three space-separated integers N X and L.
explainOutput: For each test case, on a single line, output yes if it is possible to form a stick of length L. Else output no.
explanation: There are 2 Test Cases Test Case 1: You have sticks of lengths 1 to 5 except 2. So you have sticks of length [ 1, 3, 4, 5 ] You can form a stick of length 8 using the sticks of length of 5 & 3. You can also form this stick using the sticks of length 1, 3 & 4. ( Note that you cannot form this stick using 2 sticks of length 4 because you have only 1 stick of length 4. )

name: So you think you can Think?
description:
You have a list of numbers. Currently the list consists of only one integer N. In one move, you have to do the following operations on the list in order:
  • Create a new empty list NewList
  • Iterate through your current list, and for each element X present in this list: 1. If X is Odd, append the number (X * 2) to the NewList 2. Else if X is Even, append the numbers (X * 2) and (X + 1) to the NewList 3. Delete the element X from the current list.
  • Assign NewList as the current list.
You are supposed to find the amount of Odd numbers present in your list after performing this move M times. Since this number can be very large for larger cases, output the answer Modulo (%) 10^9 + 7 (1000000007). (Refer to the explanation of the example for clarification ) Note: Remember the following property while computing the answer to avoid integer overflows:- ( A + B ) % MOD = ( A % MOD ) + ( B % MOD ).
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. Each test case consists of a single line containing two space-separated integers N and M.
explainOutput: For each test case, output the answer in a single line.
explanation: There are 3 test cases Test Case 1: Initial list -> [ 4 ] After Move 1 -> [ 8, 5 ] After Move 2 -> [ 16, 9, 10 ] Hence, there is only 1 odd number present in the final list (9). Finally since the answer is 1, and we have to output it modulo 10^9 + 7: The final answer is = 1 % (10^9 + 7) = 1 Test Case 3: There are 4807526976 odd numbers present in the final list after 49 moves. The final answer is = 4807526976 % (10^9 + 7) = 807526948 Be aware of integer overflows.

name: Shadow Clone Jutsu
description: Spring season is coming soon and so are the festivals in the leaf village. Houses, roads, shops all are being painted. All such missions are ‘D’ ranked missions which have to be given to the genins. So, all the genins of the Leaf village are given such small tasks. Naruto is one of them. He became upset again as the hokage gave him another easy mission. He is given two tasks:- 1. Paint the training ground 2. Plant 100 trees He wants to complete them all as soon as possible. So, he creates shadow clones to divide his work. He starts with the toughest job first which is to paint the training ground. The ground is a square ground. Naruto uses his chakra to create M shadow clones. The shadow clones are given equal squares from the square ground ie the ground is divided into equal sizes of smaller squares. Out of the M shadow clones, only X shadow clones (1<=X<=M) can be given this job since each shadow clone is given equal sizes of squares. You have to help Naruto calculate the maximum number of shadow clones X that can be given the job to paint the ground.
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. The first line of each test case contains an integer M denoting the number of shadow clones generated
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the integer X which is the maximum number of shadow clones that can be allotted the job to paint the ground.
explanation:
Test Case 1:
Out of the two shadow clones, only 1 can be given the job to paint the ground since the ground can’t be divided into 2 equal squares.

name: A Mission in the Land of Greens
description: Rock Lee was given a mission after a long time. He had to help the merchants in the land of Greens. He is given a straight line path ax+by=c, which leads to the land of Greens. Since it is the first time he is given a mission to be completed by himself, he got so excited that he chose a random path rx+sy = t. You have to tell them if the path he has chosen will ever intersect with the actual path which leads to the Land of Greens. Can you help him?
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. First line of each test case consists of 3 integers a, b and c where a and b both can’t be 0. Second line of each test case consists of 3 integers r, s and t where r and s both can’t be 0.
explainOutput: For each test case, print the answer to it as "YES" if the lines intersect each other ever or "NO" (both without quotes) otherwise.
explanation: Both lines intersect at a point.

name: Lady Tsunade Needs Help
description: It becomes really tiring for lady Tsunade every time there is a mission to select genins,chunins and jonins for that mission. The team has to have proper skills in order to make the mission a successful one. So, she decides to give a number to every Shinobi of the Leaf village so that it would be easier for her to select a team when a mission arrives. The number assigned to every Shinobi is the multiplication of the skills he has acquired. Lady Tsunade has to select the best possible team with the available Shinobis. Every mission is ranked X according to the difficulty of that mission. Lady Tsunade has to find the possible number of groups that can be formed with the available Shinobis. The groups formed has to have gcd % X = 0 (gcd divisible by X) in order to have a balanced group. Each group consists of 3 members. Your task is to tell the maximum number of groups of gcd % X = 0 which can be formed.
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. First line of each test case consists of two integers N and X where N denotes the size of array and X denotes the gcd required to form teams Second line consists of a series of values A[i] which denotes the number given to the Shinobis
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single line with the integer
explanation:
Test Case 1:
One of the possible teams can be {3, 9, 18}.
No other teams can be formed. (You cannot use a Shinobi multiple times)

name: Kakashi vs Shikamaru
description:
Shikamaru is known for his amazing intellect.
Kakashi decided to find out the true extent of his abilities. Kakashi gave him N cards.
Each of these cards had a number written on them in the order:
A1 A2 A3 … AN In one move, Shikamaru is allowed to do any one of the following tasks:
1) Change the number on any 1 card to any other number
2) Place the last card at the start of the sequence. (More formally, A[i+1] = A[i] for 2 <= i <= N and A[1] = A[N]) Shikamaru is supposed to make moves on this sequence of cards in such a way that the final numbers on the cards are:
1 2 3 … N
in the same order. This should be done in the minimum number of moves possible. Help Shikamaru to complete this task.
explainInput:
The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases.
The first line of each test case consists of a single integer N.
The second line consists of N space-separated integers A[i].
explainOutput: For each test case, print the minimum number of moves required in a single line
explanation:
Test case 1: After Move 1: [1 5 3 9]
After Move 2: [1 2 3 9]
After Move 3: [1 2 3 4]

name: Anand hacks Aditya’s Laptop
description: Aditya insulted Anand in front of everyone in the classroom. Anand decided to take revenge from Aditya, so he designed a plan to get Aditya's laptop for some time and hack into it and get all the important documents which he needs to blackmail him but the documents are password protected. Password is 4 spaces long which consist of digits only, ranging from 1 to 5, Anand is using brute force attack to unlock the documents. D is the no. of documents to be unlocked, T is the time after which Aditya will return, in that time you have to unlock one document and you have given the correct password, so you have to tell Anand whether it is possible to hack into Aditya's laptop before he comes. 1 sec is required for each attempt. Your attack should start form 1111. The hack is successful even if it takes exactly T seconds. As Anand helps you in doing all class assignments, you should help him in hacking into Aditya’s laptop.
explainInput: The first line of the input consists of a single integer D denoting the number of documents to be unlocked. For each D there are two lines which give you time T in seconds, followed by the correct password.
explainOutput: For each document, print a single line with “YES” if it is possible to hack the document and “NO” otherwise without the quotes.
explanation: For the first document brute force attack will start from 1111 1 sec 1112 2 sec 1113 3 sec 1114 4 sec And so on…. For 1234 it takes 39 sec which is less than 40 sec. Therefore it prints YES. For the second document, it takes 70 sec which is greater than 68. Therefore it prints NO.

name: Miu and Nodes
description: Miu is impressed by the anonymity provided by the Darknet. It is achieved by passing the user request through various nodes(computers). The process is known as the onion routing. Miu decides to simulate onion routing by creating nodes to pass the user’s request. These nodes work in such a way that a single node cannot pass two or more requests simultaneously and a node is engaged until an outgoing signal is sent for each incoming signal through that node or vice versa. Each user request has a priority level given by an integer Pi for incoming requests and outgoing requests. All incoming requests have a higher priority than outgoing requests, in case when their priorities match and hence must be processed first. Miu can not figure out the minimum number of nodes required so that no user request will get delayed. Help her. Display the optimal number of nodes required to make the system smooth.
explainInput: The first line of the input contains a single integer T, denoting the number of test cases. The description of T test cases follows - The first line contains the N number of incoming requests and M number of outgoing requests. The second line contains N space separated integers P1,P2,P3,...Pn The third line contains M space separated integers P1,P2,P3,...Pm
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line containing an integer - the minimum number of nodes required.
explanation: Test Case 1: Therefore, the minimum number of nodes required is 3.

name: Mercy and her kill list
description:
Mercy Rodgers is the deadliest hitwomen the darknet world has ever known. With over 430 brutal murders, neither has she ever missed her mark nor has she been caught even once. But one thing is very specific about Mercy, all her victims are people who had ill-treated women or children. Since she too had once been a victim of abuse, she carries every mission with full sense of revenge. Once she is given N targets, she researches and analyses the severity of each ith target’s (1 <= i <= N) misdeeds M[i], strength and security around the target which she has to break S[i] and the probable number of witnesses at the scene of murder W[i]. Mercy comes up with a way to calculate vengeance V[i] for her targets. It is
V[i] = M[i] + S[i] – W[i]
Higher the value of V, more difficult is the execution of the target and lower the V, easier is the execution. She has decided that she would start by killing the easiest target followed by the toughest target and then followed by the 2nd easiest target and so on.However, the following characteristics of Mercy must be taken into consideration:
  1. Since Mercy still has some mercy, she spares targets who have her vengeance level V[i] as multiples of 5.
  2. She gains additional confidence when she kills targets who had V[i] as multiples of 3 and not 5, so she chooses a difficult target next even if it alters the sequence.
  3. If V[i] is a multiple of both 3 and 5, she spares the target.
  4. In case multiple targets have equal level of her vengeance, the one with earlier position is executed.
Since Mercy is short of time and high on urge for revenge, you being her personal assistant help her write the order in which she has to assassinate her targets.
explainInput: The first line of input is T which denotes the number of test cases. The first line of each test case is N which denotes the total numbers of targets. The 2nd, 3rd and 4th line of each test case is a series of space separated numbers which is M[i], S[i] and W[i] respectively of the targets.
explainOutput: Each test case should output a series of integers on new line each denoting the target’s position on the kill list.
explanation: Test Case 1: The easiest target at 3rd position on the list, the toughest at 1st, 2nd easiest at 5th , 2nd toughest chapter at 4th, and the 2nd target is spared.

name: Go Corona, Corona Go
description: Since the lockdown, Mithil has been coding just to end his boredom. Mithil who is also a pro gamer, thinks to play a Game and put away coding for some time. So today, the game he’s playing is about Spoidy. Spoidy is initially at a location c=0. Mithil can press D and U: 'D' moves character down, setting his position to c − 1 'U' moves character up, setting his position to c + 1 But Mithil's controller is a bit old, it crashes at some instances. Sometimes few of the button presses are ignored and there is no change in Spoidy’s position. For example, if Mithil sends instructions "UUD", it might be interpreted as any of the following: UUD, UU, U, D, UD Mithil is unaware of which instructions will be sent successfully beforehand. Thus, he wants to know how many different locations may Spoidy end up at.
explainInput: The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases. The first and only line of each test case contains a string S of N commands, each either 'D' or 'U'.
explainOutput: For each test case, print a single line consisting of one integer denoting the number of different locations Spoidy may end up at.
explanation: Test Case 1: UUD = 0+1+1-1 = 1 UU = 0+1+1 = 2 U = 0+1 = 1 D = 0-1 = -1 UD = 0+1-1 = 0 Spoidy may end up anywhere between -1,0,1,2. Hence 4 unique locations.

name: Devin's Prime Time Hack
description: Devin loves to work with graphics in his free time, and due to recent viral outbreaks, he wants to try working on a new graphic software which is out in the market. However his parents won’t allow him to buy the very expensive software and the serial key cannot be easily cracked. The serial key is made up of 4 parts. Each part has a hexadecimal code. The code is valid, if the decimal conversion of each individual part of the code (N) has a prime count of factors. For example, the number "13" has 2 factors “1 and 13”. 2 is a prime number, hence 13 is valid.
explainInput:
The first line of input contains an integer T denoting the number of test cases.
Each test case consists of 1 line of 4 “-” separated hexadecimal numbers
explainOutput: For each test case, output a single word “YES” or “NO” on a single line.
explanation: Test Case 1: The first part converts to 13 in decimal which has 2 factors (1 and 13). The second part converts to 179 which has 2 factors (1 and 179). The third part converts to 191 in decimal which has 2 factors (1 and 191). The fourth part converts to 283 in decimal which has 2 factors (1 and 283). Hence the code is valid. Test Case 2: The first part converts to 2730 in decimal which has 32 factors but 32 is not prime. Hence the code is invalid.

name: Secret Info
description: Cibin, is the head of an intelligence agency. Since there is a lot of fake information, he wants to share some highly confidential information S to all the defense officials regarding this pandemic. Here the message to be sent is in a single word consisting of only lowercase English letters. For the confidentiality of the information he decides to encrypt the message. He makes a string M of length N, such that after deleting a substring of non-zero length from M, the remaining string is S. He needs your help to find out the number of all such possible ways he can form the string M. Note: The string M can be a combination of lowercase English letters.
explainInput: First line contains the number of test cases T. For each test case there is a single line which contains a space separated integer, N and a string S.
explainOutput: For each test case, output the number of possible strings modulo 10^9+7.
explanation: Following are some examples of 2 lettered words: aa, ab, az, zz, bd, etc. We can form 26*26 = 676 such words but only 51 out of them contain at least one ‘a’ so that we can form the string S. Eg: We can get ‘a’ from ‘ab’ after removing the substring ‘b’. But we can’t get ‘a’ from ‘cd’ or ‘tf’.
